title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify the fuel source that was intermediate in contribution to total electricity generated in 2011 by the ten countries, such as any of the following:

· Hydroelectric

· Nuclear

The response identifies the fuel source that was intermediate in contribution to total electricity generated in 2011 by the ten countries, such as one of the following:

· Hydroelectric

· Nuclear

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the country that produced a higher percentage of its electricity in 2011 from nonhydroelectric renewables than any other country as Germany.
The response identifies the country that produced a higher percentage of its electricity in 2011 from nonhydroelectric renewables than any other country as Germany.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem in South Korea that could result if total electricity generation was increased by 10% with its most-used fuel source, such any of the following:

· Increased air pollution such as SO x MathType@MTEF@5@5@@38C3@ , NO x MathType@MTEF@5@5@@38BE@ , VOCs MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaaeOvaiaab+eacaqGdbGaae4Caaaa@395B@ , particulate matter, CO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@386D@ , from an increase in emissions from fossil-fuel burning power plants.

· Accelerated impacts of global climate change, such as rising sea level, from an increase in carbon dioxide emissions.

· Increased instances of industrial smog/photochemical smog/acid deposition from an increase in pollutants released burning fossil fuels.

· Increased groundwater contamination/air pollution/earthquakes from an increase in fracking to extract natural gas.

· Increased thermal pollution from the return of heated coolant water from fossil-fuel burning power plants to the source of the water.

· Increased mining for fossil fuels can increase environmental costs associated with water and air pollution, and habitat loss.

· Increased likelihood of oil spills from an increase in oil drilling/use of oil rigs/transportation of oil.

The response describes one environmental problem in South Korea that could result if total electricity generation was increased by 10% with its most-used fuel source, such one of the following:

· Increased air pollution such as SO x MathType@MTEF@5@5@@38C3@ , NO x MathType@MTEF@5@5@@38BE@ , VOCs MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaaeOvaiaab+eacaqGdbGaae4Caaaa@395B@ , particulate matter, CO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@386D@ , from an increase in emissions from fossil-fuel burning power plants.

· Accelerated impacts of global climate change, such as rising sea level, from an increase in carbon dioxide emissions.

· Increased instances of industrial smog/photochemical smog/acid deposition from an increase in pollutants released burning fossil fuels.

· Increased groundwater contamination/air pollution/earthquakes from an increase in fracking to extract natural gas.

· Increased thermal pollution from the return of heated coolant water from fossil-fuel burning power plants to the source of the water.

· Increased mining for fossil fuels can increase environmental costs associated with water and air pollution, and habitat loss.

· Increased likelihood of oil spills from an increase in oil drilling/use of oil rigs/transportation of oil.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not propose a solution to reduce an environmental problem linked to the primary fuel source used to generate electricity in Brazil, other than reduced used of the fuel source, such as any of the following:

· Use fish ladders/or other appropriate mitigation devices to enable fish population to move upstream in dammed rivers.

· Regulate land use around river basins upstream to reduce erosion/sedimentation in reservoir.

· Regulate land use upstream to reduce organic material from entering streams to reduce greenhouse gas/methane emissions from reservoirs.

· Install aeration devices in the reservoir to increase dissolved oxygen content for aquatic organisms.

· Implement multi-level water intakes to ensure that water released from the reservoir into the rivers has an appropriate temperature and dissolved oxygen level.

The response proposes a solution to reduce an environmental problem linked to the primary fuel source used to generate electricity in Brazil, other than reduced used of the fuel source, such as one of the following:

· Use fish ladders/or other appropriate mitigation devices to enable fish population to move upstream in dammed rivers.

· Regulate land use around river basins upstream to reduce erosion/sedimentation in reservoir.

· Regulate land use upstream to reduce organic material from entering streams to reduce greenhouse gas/methane emissions from reservoirs.

· Install aeration devices in the reservoir to increase dissolved oxygen content for aquatic organisms.

· Implement multi-level water intakes to ensure that water released from the reservoir into the rivers has an appropriate temperature and dissolved oxygen level.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that supports or refutes the hypothesis that the total ecological footprint of Canada was larger than that of Brazil, such as any of the following:

· This is supported. Canada has a much smaller population than Brazil, but Canada has a larger ecological footprint because Canada generates more total energy than Brazil.

· This is supported. Based on per capita energy use and population size, Canada generates more total electricity than Brazil and thus has a larger ecological footprint.

The response makes a claim that supports or refutes the hypothesis that the total ecological footprint of Canada was larger than that of Brazil, such as one of the following:

· This is supported. Canada has a much smaller population than Brazil, but Canada has a larger ecological footprint because Canada generates more total energy than Brazil.

· This is supported. Based on per capita energy use and population size, Canada generates more total electricity than Brazil and thus has a larger ecological footprint.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that supports or refutes the proposed action to sell food from bulk food bins in place of individually packaged quantities of food to reduce the ecological footprint of the community, such as the following:

· Expanding bulk bins in grocery stores should reduce the ecological footprint because they reduce the need for packaging and waste generated from packaging. Packaging requires resource extraction/energy use/waste disposal, so reduced packaging would reduce the ecological footprint.

The response makes a claim that supports or refutes the proposed action to sell food from bulk food bins in place of individually packaged quantities of food to reduce the ecological footprint of the community, such as the following:

· Expanding bulk bins in grocery stores should reduce the ecological footprint because they reduce the need for packaging and waste generated from packaging. Packaging requires resource extraction/energy use/waste disposal, so reduced packaging would reduce the ecological footprint.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one regulatory practice that could reduce the effect of passenger vehicles on carbon oxides in the atmosphere, such as any of the following:

· Implement legislation to improve fuel quality standards/increase fuel efficiency of vehicles.

· Support/implement stricter vehicle emissions standards; require more frequent vehicle inspections specifically on older model vehicles.

· Invest/support research/use of alternative fuels, such biofuels like ethanol and biodiesel.

· Invest/support research/use of non-food-crop biofuels, such as those made from algae and switchgrass rather than corn.

· Increase funding for public transportation to reduce the number of vehicles emitting carbon dioxide.

· Incentives to increase carpooling to reduce the number of vehicles emitting carbon dioxide.

· Incentives to switch to driving electric cars to reduce vehicle emissions.

The response describes one regulatory practice that could reduce the effect of passenger vehicles on carbon oxides in the atmosphere, such as one of the following:

· Implement legislation to improve fuel quality standards/increase fuel efficiency of vehicles.

· Support/implement stricter vehicle emissions standards; require more frequent vehicle inspections specifically on older model vehicles.

· Invest/support research/use of alternative fuels, such biofuels like ethanol and biodiesel.

· Invest/support research/use of non-food-crop biofuels, such as those made from algae and switchgrass rather than corn.

· Increase funding for public transportation to reduce the number of vehicles emitting carbon dioxide.

· Incentives to increase carpooling to reduce the number of vehicles emitting carbon dioxide.

· Incentives to switch to driving electric cars to reduce vehicle emissions.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe an additional benefit, other than reducing the air pollutant mentioned, that could result from the regulatory practice identified in part (g), such as any of the following:

Implement legislation to improve fuel quality standards/increase fuel efficiency of vehicles (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

· Decreased use/purchase of gasoline, which would decrease reliance on fossil fuels and greenhouse gas emissions

Support/implement stricter vehicle emissions standards; require more frequent vehicle inspections specifically on older model vehicles (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

· Decrease in vehicular accidents and subsequent injuries/deaths caused by faulty/old vehicle parts/engines

Invest/support research/use of alternative fuels, such biofuels like ethanol and biodiesel (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

Invest/support research/use of non-food-crop biofuels, such as those made from algae and switchgrass rather than corn (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

· Algae can be grown in wastewater from sewage treatment plants, reducing eutrophication from excessive of nutrients

· Growing switchgrass in the United States can provide wildlife habitat since it is a native grass

· There is a decrease in soil erosion and less depletion of carbon in the soil by growing/harvesting switchgrass than food crops such as corn

Increased funding for public transportation or incentives to increase carpooling (regulatory practice in part (g)).

· Reduce traffic congestion, commute times

· Decreased emission of other pollutants (such as heavy metals, particulates)

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Improved public health/decreased human health effects from pollutants (respiratory problems/heart disease/eye irritation)

· Improved ecosystem health from reduced pollutants in atmosphere

· Economic benefit of less sickness, reduced medical costs/expenses, fewer lost workdays

· Decreased use/purchase of gasoline, which would decrease reliance on fossil fuels and greenhouse gas emissions

· Decreased formation of photochemical smog/acid precipitation

· Decreased production of ozone

· Decreased use/purchase of gasoline, which would decrease reliance on fossil fuels and greenhouse gas emissions
